---
title: "Getting Started"
---

## Requirements

- CMake 3.14 or higher
- C++17 compatible compiler (GCC 8+, Clang 7+, or Apple Clang 11+)
- Git (for fetching dependencies)

## Building from Source

### Basic Build

```bash
# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/jimhester/simdcsv.git
cd simdcsv

# Configure with CMake (Release build)
cmake -B build -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release

# Build
cmake --build build
```

### Debug Build

For development with debug symbols:

```bash
cmake -B build -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Debug
cmake --build build
```

### Build with Code Coverage

To generate code coverage reports:

```bash
cmake -B build -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Debug -DENABLE_COVERAGE=ON
cmake --build build
```

## Running Tests

The test suite includes 79 tests covering well-formed CSV parsing and error handling:

```bash
# Run all tests with CTest
cd build && ctest --output-on-failure

# Or run specific test binaries
./build/simdcsv_test           # 42 well-formed CSV tests
./build/error_handling_test    # 37 error handling tests
./build/csv_parsing_test       # Integration tests
```

## Running Benchmarks

To benchmark parser performance:

```bash
./build/simdcsv_benchmark
```

## Command Line Tool

The build produces an `scsv` command line tool for working with CSV files:

```bash
# Count rows in a CSV file
scsv count data.csv

# Display first 10 rows
scsv head data.csv

# Select specific columns by name or index
scsv select -c name,age data.csv

# Pretty-print with aligned columns
scsv pretty data.csv

# Get file info (rows, columns, dialect)
scsv info data.csv
```

See the [CLI Documentation](cli.qmd) for complete usage information.

## Dependencies

All dependencies are automatically fetched via CMake's FetchContent:

| Dependency | Version | Purpose |
|------------|---------|---------|
| [Google Highway](https://github.com/google/highway) | 1.3.0 | Portable SIMD abstraction |
| [Google Test](https://github.com/google/googletest) | 1.14.0 | Unit testing framework |
| [Google Benchmark](https://github.com/google/benchmark) | 1.8.3 | Performance benchmarking |

## Usage Example

```cpp
#include "two_pass.h"
#include "io_util.h"

int main() {
    // Load CSV file with SIMD-aligned padding
    auto [buf, len] = simdcsv::load_file("data.csv");

    // Initialize parser with thread count
    simdcsv::two_pass parser;
    auto idx = parser.init(len, 4);  // 4 threads

    // Parse the file
    parser.parse(buf, idx, len);

    // Access field indexes...
    return 0;
}
```

## Error Handling

simdcsv provides three error handling modes for different use cases:

```cpp
#include "error.h"
#include "two_pass.h"

// Strict mode - stop on first error
simdcsv::ErrorCollector errors(simdcsv::ErrorMode::STRICT);

// Permissive mode - collect all errors, try to recover
simdcsv::ErrorCollector errors(simdcsv::ErrorMode::PERMISSIVE);

// Best-effort mode - ignore errors, parse what's possible
simdcsv::ErrorCollector errors(simdcsv::ErrorMode::BEST_EFFORT);

// Parse with error collection
simdcsv::two_pass parser;
auto idx = parser.init(len, 1);
parser.parse_with_errors(buf, idx, len, errors);

// Check results
if (errors.has_errors()) {
    std::cerr << errors.summary() << std::endl;
}
```

See [Error Handling](error-handling.qmd) for detailed documentation.
